channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15563] 'counter' may overflow in BoundedGroupingStrategy
item.description:
groupName = groupNames[counter.getAndIncrement() % groupNames.length];

Theoretically, counter can overflow and becomes negative then causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

But in practice, we need 2 billions different identifiers to make this happen, and before the overflow we will run into OOM because of a huge groupNameCache...

So not sure if it is worth to fix

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: I'd say worth the fix, but a low priority. Let's leave it marked as beginner in case someone new to the project wants something to gnaw on a bit.

Attached patch 'hbase-15563-v1.patch' switches counter to AtomicLong. Existing WAL test cases continue to pass but no new dedicated boundary tests are added.

"before the overflow we will run into OOM because of a huge groupNameCache."

Agreed, with 6GB of memory dedicated to just a ConcurrentHashMap and trying to simulate the groupNameCache region entries I topped out at 28 million cache entries. Counter's Integer.MAX_VALUE limit was a few orders of magnitude larger at 2 billion. Still, since ConcurrentHashMap size is unbound, maybe with server-sized memory allocations the limiting factor could shift to counter.

-1 overall

What about using a rotate algorithm? I mean, reset the counter value to 0 if it is already beyond the length of groupNames? AtomicLong can still overflow theoretically...

Thanks.
A microbenchmark would be good, but I expect and `if` that usually misses won't be more expensive than a modulo operation.

Below are results for time to get groupNames array element for Integer.Max_Value*2 records across multiple thread counts. Counter reset code was closely adapted from AtomicInteger.getAndIncrement().

Threads AtomicLong Run Time Counter Reset Run Time % Difference
1 65s 66s + 1.5%
2 186s 219s +16%
4 287s 317s +10%

The Counter Reset method is a little slower but still I will put it into a quick patch tonight.

Just FYI counter reset logic was:


  public static final int getAndIncrement() {

    for (;;) {

      int current = counterInt.get();

      int next = (current + 1);

      if (next == groupNames.length) {

        next = 0;

      }

      if (counterInt.compareAndSet(current, next)) return current;

    }

  }

Is it a little faster if you use


int next = (current + 1) % groupNames.length;

without the 'if'?

Thanks.

Expanded and reran the benchmark test. Counter resetting with if beat out reseting via mod and was more inline with AtomicLong this run:

Threads AtomicLong Run Time Reset With If Run Time Reset With Mod Run Time
1 66s 52s 76s
2 194s 203s 218s
4 299s 302s 315s

Attached patch 'hbase-15563-v2.patch' uses if statements as this seems the best route.
